FLU INFECTIONS

     1. Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong asked the Minister for Health (a) whether there has been an increase in flu infections over the last three months and if this is normal for this period of time; and (b) if so, whether this rise in flu infections is caused by any virus closely or remotely related to the H5N1 strain.

     The Minister for Health (Mr Khaw Boon Wan):  Mr Speaker, Sir, in Singapore, influenza viruses circulate all year round.  But over two periods every year, there would normally be an increase in influenza incidence: April to July and November to January.  They roughly correspond to the southern winter and northern winter respectively.

 

     Influenza A is the predominant circulating influenza virus here. In the last three months, its incidence peaked in the first week of January 2006, when 5.7% of all patients who presented with Acute Respiratory Infection (ARI) tested positive for Influenza A. This rate of 5.7% is, in fact, lower than the corresponding figure of 17.9% in 2004 or 7.0% in 2005.

 

     So far, H3N2 - this is the Hong Kong flu that caused an epidemic in 1968 - and H1N1, the infamous Spanish flu which caused a major problem for the world in 1918, have been the influenza virus subtypes in circulation.  To date, H5N1 has not been identified in Singapore, whether among humans or birds.

     Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong (Non-Constituency Member):  Sir, anecdotal evidence from many people I talked to tells me that this is a very strong virus, and people are suffering very badly from the cough.  It seems that this is something different.  Is there a special medicine for this?  Or is it something that normal medicine is able to cure the flu?

     Mr Khaw Boon Wan:  Sir, I wonder where did Mr Chia get his anecdotes from because, fortunately, there is no H5N1 yet in Singapore.  He may have friends in Indonesia or Vietnam, but most of them who got it have died.  The symptoms are the usual flu and severe pneumonia with many complications.  The fatality rate is high.  I think the recorded cases in about seven countries is more than 100.  The fatality rate is more than half.

 

     So this is a serious problem.  Fortunately, for human beings, the problem remains one that largely affects the animals.  There is now a world pandemic.  We see it in Germany, Turkey, Africa, among the birds.  It remains among the birds.  The risk is that one day, the virus will mutate and become much more infectious - spreading from human to human.  And that is why all of us have to quickly gear up and we have been doing so, like any other country.

    Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong:  Sir, today's Straits Times has an article advising the shut-down of businesses and Government in the event of a pandemic when the virus is able to transfer to humans.  Is the Government prepared for such a contingency to shut-down the whole Government, all systems and all companies in the event of such a pandemic?  Are we prepared for this?  What are the likely consequences of such a shut-down?

     Mr Khaw Boon Wan:  Sir, preparations take the form of the Flu Pandemic Preparedness Plan which, by now, practically all countries would have it.  We have been refining our Plan for a couple of years now, and it is fully published in the website.  Like all plans, you can never be fully prepared, because while the risk now is H5N1, when it happens, will it actually be H5N1 or some other virus?  Nature has a way to surprise.  But there are certain generic principles which we can follow to gear up as much as we can.  And we will continue to refine our plan.  We have, in fact, discussed it in this House not too many months ago in response to some Members' query. 

 

     My own assessment is this.  I think our own domestic preparation plan is as good as one can get.  But in the last few months, we have devoted our energy to work upstream, on the preventive aspects.  And it is possible to prevent it.  The world has a window to prevent this disaster from happening, but it requires cooperation from many countries, especially those with large agricultural sectors.  That is why we work with our neighbours.  In fact, Members would have read and I have spoken about it in this House that we are doing a major project helping Indonesia, working not just between our two countries but involving America and many other countries.  In fact, they are right now in town to discuss this pilot project, and I am meeting them tonight.

     Mr Speaker: Last supplementary question, Mr Chia.

     Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong:  Sir, now that a lot of poultry are affected in many other countries, should citizens make a conscious effort to avoid chickens and ducks in the meantime?

     Mr Khaw Boon Wan:  Sir, although I eat very little meat, I continue to occasionally eat Kentucky fried chickens.  This H5N1 reminds me of the SARS virus.  While it is fearsome when it spreads, it is easily killed outside of a host.  At a temperature of 60 degrees, I think, the virus is killed.  Therefore, if the chicken is properly cooked, eggs are properly boiled, the risk is almost zero.  Therefore, when Singaporeans travel overseas, just stay away from chicken farms and wet markets where slaughtering continues.  When we stopped the slaughtering of poultry in wet markets 15 years ago, there was a lot of unhappiness coming from housewives.  But what an important contribution it has made to our public health.  It has reduced significantly this risk.

     Mdm Ho Geok Choo (West Coast):  Sir, the Minister indicated that at a temperature of 60 degrees or so, it will be very safe.  Many eateries are still serving half-boiled eggs.  I wonder whether it is good for us to issue an advisory for Singaporeans to avoid half-boiled eggs.

     Mr Khaw Boon Wan:  Sir, I personally do not think that is necessary because our AVA is very vigilant.  Last fortnight when a case cropped up in Malaysia - kampong chickens were infected with H5N1 - they moved at a fast speed to reduce the risk.  For the past two years, they have been inspecting farms in Malaysia and making sure that the chicken farms which export to us are properly bio-secured.  The risk therefore is very low, as we only import chickens from these areas.  In Singapore, a large proportion of our eggs are locally supplied, and AVA has made sure that our farms in Singapore are properly bio-secured.  Unless you start smuggling eggs from I do not know where, I think it is quite safe to continue eating your boiled eggs.

INDIVIDUAL EMAIL ACCOUNTS FOR SINGAPOREANS

     The following Question stood in the name of Mr Leong Horn Kee -

 

     2.  To ask the Minister for Information, Communications and the Arts in view of the announcement made by the Government to provide ultra high-speed broadband and wireless Internet connections for the whole of  Singapore, whether his Ministry will consider issuing in future an individual email account for every student, working adult and active Singaporean interested in Internet usage so as to facilitate the conveyance of school materials, business communications, Government information and notices among people.

     Ms Indranee Rajah (Tanjong Pagar):  Question No. 2, Sir.

     The Minister for Information, Communications and the Arts (Dr Lee Boon Yang):  Mr Speaker, Sir, Singapore already has one of the highest Internet access and infocomm savvy population in the world.  The Infocomm Development Authority's latest Annual Survey of Infocomm Usage in Households and by Individuals  shows that 66% of households enjoy Internet access.  Over three-quarters of companies  made use of the Internet.  Singaporeans are Internet-savvy and sophisticated in our Internet usage with 61% of Singapore's resident population aged 15 years and above using the Internet regularly.  Email is the top Internet application used.  About 94% surveyed said that they used email.  This means that a high percentage of our people already have an existing email account.  Of these accounts, some may be personal paid accounts offered by access service providers such as SingNet or Pacific Internet, personal free accounts obtained from providers such as Google and Yahoo, or accounts issued by MINDEF, schools and their employers.  In fact, many Singaporeans have more than one email account.

 

     Does the Government need to compete against existing service providers in issuing and maintaining email accounts for every Singaporean?   To do so, the Government will need to expend additional resources in hardware, software and manpower. 

 

    The case supporting the potential benefit from such free email accounts is not strong.  From focus group discussions conducted by IDA, individuals have generally expressed their preference to use their existing personal email accounts rather than a new Government-issued email account.  This could be because many people already have a problem managing multiple accounts for both personal use and their work.

 

    Process-wise, we cannot assume that every Singaporean will diligently access the Government issued email accounts to maintain direct communications with the Government agencies, such as the IRAS or CPF.  This means that the Government will still need to continue with its current efforts to communicate with Singaporeans through a variety of media and also private communication channels.  Hence, while email communication may be instantaneous and technically efficient, in practice, taking such an approach may not significantly affect public communications between the Government and the people.

 

    Nevertheless, Government will continue to evaluate the various ways through which we can communicate more effectively with Singaporeans, taking into consideration practicality, cost effectiveness and customers' usage patterns and preferences.

     Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong:  Sir, a supplementary question for the Minister regarding the ultra high-speed broadband service.  What is the estimated speed that we are looking at and at what cost?  Also, will consumers be tied down with two to three years' contract with the service providers once the system is up, like what we are experiencing now?  Consumers are all tied down?  Are we expected to be tied down?

     Dr Lee Boon Yang: Mr Speaker, Sir, with regard to the next generation infocomm infrastructure, which the Prime Minister announced in his Budget Statement, I seek the Member's patience.  As the Prime Minister has said, the details will be announced during the Committee of Supply.

 

     On his other point about consumers being tied down to the various packages, I do not think that is an accurate reflection.  Today, there are many different packages being offered by Internet service providers.  The consumers have a wide range of choices.  It is really up to them to choose a package that they feel is appropriate or suitable for their needs.  Today, we have dial-up packages that go for as low as only $5.20 per month.  And for broadband, we have packages that are as low as $19.90 per month, with limits to the data that can be accessed or downloaded.  There are also daily plans going for as low as below $3 a day.  In fact, the consumers do have a range of choices.  Each comes with its own terms and conditions.  So the Member cannot say that consumers are tied down.  Having decided


to adopt a particular plan, you go along with the conditions that you have agreed to.  But it is not as if all service providers (or ISPs) are providing only fixed plans, minimum three or five years.  There is a whole range of options available to Internet users and it is really up to them to choose the plan that is most appropriate to their requirements and needs.

     Mr Speaker:  Last question for you, Mr Chia.

     Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong:  Thank you, Sir.  My experience and research tell me that that is not the case.  We are all tied down, depending on the terms of contract for the services.  If you do not accept the terms of contract by the service provider, you have to pay a very high price.  That is why I terminated my Singnet account because they refused to give me a monthly contract but a minimum contract of one year, which I disagreed.  So we are being tied down.  That is something that I want to clarify with the Minister.

     Dr Lee Boon Yang:  Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member's personal experience does not nullify my point, which is that there is a whole range of service packages available. It is up to you to choose.  If you want a daily package, some companies will offer you a daily package.  If you want a monthly package, they will do so.  If you want a monthly package for one year, two or three years, they will offer it to you.  So it is up to you to decide which one you want.

     Mr Speaker:  End of Question time.

      Head P - Ministry of Home Affairs (cont.)

 

      Resumption of Debate on Question [1st March, 2006],

 

      "That the total sum to be allocated for Head P of the Estimates be reduced by $100." - [Ms Indranee Rajah].

 

      Question again proposed.

 

     Checkpoints

 

     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir):  Sir, I have two points to make.  One is on the checkpoint and the other one is on traffic jams at that checkpoint.

 

     Sir, there is a need to tighten the security at Woodlands Checkpoint. Recently, there were two murderers who escaped from Singapore to Malaysia by just slipping through the Woodlands Checkpoint.  I wonder if a terrorist can do the same after letting off a bomb in Singapore.

 

     The second point is on the traffic jams at the Woodlands Checkpoint.  Sir, I had complained of this last year and I believe the Minister promised to deploy more manpower there.  Anyone, having travelled through the Checkpoint, will notice that the jams are still there.  They are very crowded especially during peak hours.  But I notice that during the peak hours, many of the check-in booths were left vacant and empty.  I wonder whether they can be manned with manpower.

     Handling the Young

 

     Mr Tan Soo Khoon (East Coast):  Sir, recently the Police announced that it would check on teenagers who are found loitering on the streets after 11.00 pm.  The aim of this move, according to the Police, is to reduce the incidence of crime amongst young people.  I think the aim is a good one but somehow this has caused some unease amongst the people who are affected, namely, the young people,  and they are unhappy about the Police playing the role of nanny.  Many of them resent the notion of being stopped by the Police and being checked on although, as we know, the Police have a right to check on everyone, young and old.

 

     As a parent, I too would be concerned if my own children were to be wandering aimlessly on the streets late at night.  But I think that young people have a point when they start to think that the Police action will amount to an infringement on their personal freedom.  The police announcement conjures up notions of Gestapo-like checks on young people and sweeping them off the streets after 11.00 pm, and I attribute this misunderstanding on the part of young people to poor communication by the Police of what is basically a good intention.  It was only when the Police clarified some days later that it was never intended to be what was obviously a misconception that perceptions changed.  But I think the Police would have to go beyond merely placating young people by words now.  It would have to show by its action that it will be discerning in its search and queries so that its image is not damaged in the eyes of young people.

 

     A clear communication of good intentions is a must, especially when we are dealing with young people.  It brings to my mind the recent incident when the Police warned a group of schoolgirls about selling T-shirts with elephants printed on them at a fund-raising event and wearing them en masse.  My first reaction on hearing about this was that this was something unbelievable.  What is wrong with selling white T-shirts with elephants on them, just because they were seen to be symbolising the unhappiness over the delay in opening Buangkok Station?  After all, other organisations also have their members wearing white and white, no doubt without elephants.  Sir, it took no less than the Minister himself - and I am glad he did it quickly - to say that the Police action was wrong.  And as my colleague, Mr Charles Chong, pointed out, it was just a no brainer on the part of the Police.  If not for this clarification being made quickly, I think the Police might have just lost some credibility.

 

     Sir, society is loosening up.  Young people nowadays behave differently from those of my generation.  It is just a loosening up of society that we are all going through.  What adults may view as loitering on the part of the young, the young consider that they are merely, what they say, hanging out or chilling out with their friends.  It is probably a harmless activity, and we must therefore adopt a balanced approach.  Where they have done wrong, we have to take necessary steps, and the best way is preventive action through education, and that is the job of parents and teachers.  Tell them that crime does not pay.  But a knee-jerk approach in handling the problem may in the end cause more harm than good. Sir, I think what we need to do is to show young people that the law is with them, not against them.

     Curfew on Youths

 

     Mr Chiam See Tong:  Sir, in the past, the Police used to organise Boys' Club.  I think that is a very good thing rather than putting a curfew on the youths of today.  The Boys' Club, I think, is more meaningful.  They can keep the boys away from the streets and also keep them away from doing mischief.  The Boys' Club can teach these boys social skills.  I think this Boys' Club should be revived rather than to impose curfew on the youths, which, I believe, is counter-productive.

          The Chairman:  Mr Wee Siew Kim is not here.  Mr Loh Meng See.

     Foreign Workers

 

     Mr Loh Meng See (Jalan Besar):  Sir, on the subject of foreign workers, I wish to ask the Ministry of Home Affairs to exercise restraint in the issue of liquor licence to provision shop outlets operating 24 hours and even coffeeshops in housing estates.  I would also like to ask MHA to provide a channel for the grassroots organisations and the community to be able to raise objections to the issue of liquor licence in the housing estates.

 

     Sir, in my constituency in the Beach Road area, the problem has worsened with foreign workers congregating there, and residents are very unhappy because of their excessive drinking, getting into fights, making lots of noise and disturbing the peace. They also urinate and litter, posing health concerns to our people.  And what is developing is that the locals are also taking up to the drinking habit, especially with the cheap liquor available. Two years ago, we were able to persuade the Liquor Licensing Board to stop the renewal of the liquor licence but they have since revived it and allowed it to continue.  I believe the social cost far outweighs the liberal attitude that we adopt in making alcohol, especially the cheap ones, available.  The young and the locals are beginning to get hooked in the drinking habit.

 

     Sir, we will not want to have a situation whereby alcohol is purchased and people are drinking in the streets, five-foot-ways and common areas.  In fact, this is something that is not the desired situation that we want.  People can enjoy their drinks in the privacy of their homes and in places that are not in common areas.  And I think this is a trend that we want to stop.

     The Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Home Affairs (Mr Wong Kan Seng): Sir, yesterday, most of the MPs had spoken.  And among those who were not here yesterday, an opportunity for them to speak was given this morning.  From the English press reports, I notice that the emphasis seems to be on crime, KPIs and related issues concerning the Police.  I want to deal with this first, although it is not the most important subject today that we have to deal with, particularly looking at the security situation that we face.  But I want to get this subject over with so that I can explain to Members how to look at this issue of crime, KPIs and related issues from the proper perspective.  I will then spend a bit of time talking about the more important subject, which is security, terrorism, counter-terrorism and how to prepare ourselves in the event of such a bomb explosion happening in Singapore.  My Senior Minister of State and Senior Parliamentary Secretary will then answer specifically some of the other issues raised by Members.

 

     Sir, a number of MPs have asked about the crime situation.  While crime remains an area of the Ministry's work, let us not lose focus on the seriousness of the terrorism situation that we continue to face.  That said, let me now get into the details of this overall crime situation.

 

     Yes, there has been an increase in crime rate by 19.9%, almost 20%, from 30,620 cases in 2004 to 36,700 cases in 2005.  And I do feel that this increase is alarming.  But if we were to examine the types of crime which have seen an increase, we will note that many of these crimes need not have happened, had the victims been more careful and vigilant. Many crimes were opportunistic in nature and could have been prevented if the victims were more responsible in taking care of their belongings.

 

     The bulk of the increase in crime rate can be attributed to minor theft and related offences, such as theft in dwelling and other theft.  Handphone crime featured prominently in the increases for several offences, most notably robbery, snatch theft and other theft.

 

     Mr Ahmad Khalis has rightly pointed out that there has been a significant increase in cheating and related offences, housebreaking and snatch theft.  The increase in cheating and related offences is due in part to a rise in cases of criminal breach of trust.  Many of these involved handphones.  A typical example is that of a culprit who fails to return the victim's handphone after borrowing it.  They will say, “May I borrow your phone?�?, and they will walk away, or run.

     On housebreaking, there was an increase of some 230 cases, from 1,240 in 2004 to 1,470 cases in 2005.

There was also an increase of 48 house-breaking involving culprits who gained entry through unsecured windows or doors.  There was no sign of tampering of the premises.  This suggests that the residents themselves had failed to secure their premises before they left their homes or before they went to sleep.  Such crimes can be avoided if they take care to ensure their homes are well secured.  Home-owners can prevent such crimes by installing alarm system to deter housebreakers and when it sounds, even if they are not at home, the neighbours can be alerted and I am sure would-be house-breakers would take precaution and run away.  In 2005, there were 23 serial house-breakers arrested for a total of 257 cases, compared to 28 serial house-breakers arrested for 208 cases in 2004. 

 

     Mr Khalis asked if there are special efforts to rehabilitate such serial offenders.  While Prison does not have special rehabilitation programmes for serial house-breakers, it will customise the rehabilitation programmes based on the individual and his level of needs and the risk of offending.  The programmes address the offenders' criminal thinking that causes offending behaviours and also help to impart pro-social life skills to them.

 

     As for snatch theft, where a person's belonging is forcibly snatched away from him, cases involving handphones have increased from 160 in 2004 to 280 in 2005.  These 280 cases accounted for 45% of the snatch theft cases in 2005.  Of particular concern are cases that target the handphones of young victims, which have increased from 50 cases to 93 cases in 2005.  Robbery and theft cases involving handphones remain a key area of concern for the Police.  The number of such cases increased significantly by 42% to 4,830 cases in 2005.  This is due to the higher mobile phone penetration rate in Singapore, thereby giving to a larger pool of potential victims.  Do you know how many handphone subscribers there are in Singapore?  4.3 million.  So we must look at roughly 5,000 cases in the perspective of almost 4.3 million handphone subscribers in Singapore.

 

     Similarly, just looking back at the years of the 1950s, I am sure we will find bicycle thefts were high because those were the days we travelled on a bicycle.  But today, possibly bicycle thefts are not of the same significance compared to handphones.  In the 1950s, it would be zero handphone theft because no handphone was available.

 

     Sir, on KPIs, the increase in theft and related offences, especially in relation to handphones, is one of the reasons for the increase in the number of seizable offences, as reflected in the KPIs of MHA in the Budget book.  Another key reason for this increase is more intensive Police enforcement against drink driving, which reflects the Home Team's commitment to keep our roads safe.

 

     Now, I will address Mr Low Thia Khiang's and Mr Charles Chong's query about the Ministry's KPI indicators specifically.  May I say that, except for an increase in the crime trend, the Home Team has met, if not exceeded, most of its key performance targets for FY 2004, and is expected to do as well for 2005 despite heightened security demands and limited resources.

     The Senior Minister of State for Home Affairs (Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee): Sir, first let me respond to Ms Indranee Rajah's and Mr Charles Chong's queries on child sex tourism and the Penal Code review.

 

     Ms Rajah expressed the concern regarding the sexual exploitation of minors. Sir, I share her concerns.  We have and will continue to prosecute offenders with the full extent of the law.  We are also exploring other ways to enhance protection of minors who, because they lack maturity, are especially vulnerable to exploitation.  The Inter-Agency Committee on review of sexual offences, which I chair, has been studying this issue. 

 

     First, let me address the problem of young persons engaging in prostitution.  While prostitution is not an offence in Singapore, young persons should be protected from providing sexual services.  Being more easily influenced, their consent can be impaired.  As such, they are more vulnerable to being trafficked, controlled and exploited by pimps and traffickers who prey on them and live off their earnings.  The existing legal age of consent for sexual activities is 16 years.  Although there is no evidence to suggest that there is a problem of significant numbers of 16 and 17 year olds engaging in prostitution in Singapore, there should be a higher age of protection for commercial sexual activities.  As such, Sir, we intend to make it an offence for any person to purchase sexual services from another person who is under 18 years of age.  Other countries, such as the UK and New Zealand have adopted a similar approach.  This move is part of the wider approach we are adopting to protect young persons against engaging in commercial sexual activities and possible exploitation and not specifically in response to the possible sexual victimisation of the young via the Internet which Ms Indranee had touched on.

 

     Sir, next, I would deal with the issue of child sex tourism.  Sir, child sex tourists take advantage of the inability or unwillingness of the host country to prosecute them.  I think, Ms Indranee Rajah, in fact, gave a picture of who these people may be, who may look innocuous on the outside but terrible inside.  Meanwhile, very often, prosecution at home is constrained by the lack of jurisdiction as most countries do not extend extra-territorial jurisdiction over sexual offences.  Presently, Singaporeans who have sex with minors in other countries cannot be prosecuted in Singapore as our courts do not have jurisdiction over them.  Members had earlier urged the Government to stop our nationals from preying on minors in other countries by denying them a safe haven through enacting legislation with extra-territorial effect.  Sir, we have taken note of these views and have factored them into our review.  The Inter-Agency Committee has studied laws governing sex with minors overseas in other countries.  Countries that have extended jurisdiction overseas include Australia, Canada, Hong Kong, Japan, New Zealand, UK and the US. 

 

     Sir, while we do not condone sexual exploitation of minors in other countries by our nationals, we also recognise that if extra-territorial jurisdiction is introduced, it would be challenging to investigate and prosecute cases involving offences committed by Singaporeans in other countries.  Ms Rajah mentioned some of these obstacles yesterday in this House, such as language barriers and the different local conditions, making it difficult to trace and interview foreign witnesses and to gather evidence.  The Singapore Police has no powers of investigation overseas and would have to rely principally on the cooperation of its foreign counterparts.  Sir, I have explained these difficulties in Parliament, taking the opportunity also to urge host countries to do their part to toughen their laws and enforce them vigorously.  At the same time, I said that we will continue to study the issue and monitor developments in other countries. 

 

     Our point was that efforts in this regard must be a collaborative one.  Enacting extra-territorial laws by itself is no panacea.  Sir, I am happy to note that what we said in Parliament, our exchanges galvanised action on several fronts.  But still, despite the constraints and difficulties, we recognise that having sex with minors anywhere is, indeed, deplorable.  Hence, the Government has decided to amend our laws to extend extra-territorial jurisdiction over our nationals who sexually exploit minors overseas.  I agree with Ms Rajah that by doing so we send a strong signal that we are against this appalling act and, hopefully, it will also act as a deterrent.

 

    The measures against child sex tourism will be introduced as part of the legislative changes that we will make once we have completed the review of the Penal Code, a pet topic of Mr Charles Chong who has asked once again for an update.  Sir, this review has taken a long time.  It has been prolonged because, I am sure Mr Chong understands, the Penal Code with more than 500 sections is a very important piece of legislation and we want to be as thorough as possible in reviewing it.  After all, this is the first comprehensive, holistic review of the Penal Code that we have undertaken for a long time.  Moreover, the review has stretched out because, as we went along, new issues surfaced.  For example, the impact of technology such as the Internet and mobile phones which have become an integral part of the lifestyle in Singapore and which is increasingly employed by criminals to perpetrate their criminal activities, has delayed our progress somewhat.  But, let me assure Mr Chong that we will indeed be completing our review soon.  Thereafter, as I have said, we intend to carry out a public consultation exercise at which time Mr Chong and other members of the public, including the Law Society, would be welcome to give their comments.

 

     Sir, let me now move on to the topic of youth crime and our recently announced initiative to keep our youths safe, which Mr Tan Soo Khoon had alluded to in his speech.  Last year, nearly 4,600 youths were arrested - actually it is a drop of some 8% from the year before.  Youth crime statistics for rioting, shop and other thefts, actually fell 16% and 3% respectively, last year compared to the year before.  Hence, let me assure Mr Fong that our youth gang situation is under control.  I am happy to assure him that his hypothesis that there may be a "staggering number" of youth gang members in Singapore, does not accord with reality.  But I have said many times before that every youth crime is one crime too many.  Moreover the drop of 8% is only for one year.  Before that, for two to three years, the number of youths arrested actually was rising, so it is not time to bring out the beer, not the time to celebrate yet.  Beer is something that Mr Loh Meng See has talked about just now.  So we will not drink beer here.  Nevertheless, although the youth crime situation has improved, from 2004 to 2005, youths continue to be involved in shop thefts and other thefts and also rioting ,and youths are also victims of offences, such as snatch theft, robbery, rioting and outraging of modesty, where the numbers have increased.  This is a phenomenon that bears study.  The increase in the number of youth victims of snatch theft and robbery can be mainly attributed to more youths being targeted for handphones.  

 

     Mr Fong has suggested inculcating in students an understanding of the consequences of committing crime.  That is a good point.  Indeed, let me assure Mr Fong that we have been doing this through the Inter-Ministry Committee on Youth Crime  (IMYC) which I chair.  So, for example, 2004, IMYC launched the Prison Visit Education Programme for Schools (PVEPS), a joint project involving the Police, MOE and the Prisons Department.  Under this programme, at risk youths in schools are sent to the prisoners' living environment, taste the food that the prisoners eat and also get locked up in the prison cell for a while.  They also witness a mock caning, all of which, I am sure, has a sobering experience.  Mr Fong suggests that we extend this to all students.  Let me say that this will certainly stretch the Prison's resources.  I do not think there is a need for us to do that.  It is a focused approach where resources are maximised and it will dilute our message if we let all the students undergo this.

     In March this year, the Police and the NPCC also piloted the NPCC Police Youth Ambassador Programme, where NPCC cadets will be equipped with crime prevention and problem solving skills.  With these skills the cadets will help to impart crime prevention messages to their peers and assist the schools in addressing youth-related issues.  Thirty-two secondary schools would be participating in the pilot phase. 

 

     I am happy to report that there are also other partners involved.  For example, the Law Society has been holding its Law Awareness Project through talks, the launching of a newsletter and also a website.  They inject their expertise by informing youths and young people about the consequences of their crime, and that is Mr Fong's point, not just the legal consequences but the social and personal consequences of what they do.  And, indeed, the Singapore Association of Women Lawyers actually published a very good useful "Teens and the Law" handbook which talks directly to the students.  My point is that we are all doing our part to help our youths realise their full potential and to also extend helping hands to those at risk and who may fall into trouble.  But Mr Tan has rightly mentioned that parents are a pivotal group and this is what the recent initiative was actually meant to do - to partner parents, to let them know that we are partners with them and, through this measure, through the knowledge of information given to them, that they could be more effective as a parent.

     Mr Fong asked about our efforts in helping ex-offenders reintegrate into society so as to prevent them from being dragged into a vicious cycle of criminalisation.  Mr Fong asked about the recidivism rate.  First, let me say, at the outset, that MHA is committed to assisting ex-offenders reintegrate back into society.  Working closely with community partners again, our reintegration efforts begin from the time the offenders serve their sentence in prison and continue after their release.

 

     During incarceration, offenders acquire useful skills through employment and workshops.  Currently, 26 firms operate different industries in prisons employing more than 2,000 offenders.  Offenders also enhance their employability and educational qualifications through literacy and vocational courses.  In the year 2005, more than 4,000 offenders were trained in areas such as landscaping, cleaning, IT skills and food preparation.

 

     Upon release, an ex-offender who requests for aftercare support will be given counselling and assistance by the Community Action for the Rehabilitation of Ex-Offenders (CARE) network, again comprising key partners like SCORE, SANA and so forth.  At the same time, SCORE assists in the job placement of offenders as well as ex-offenders  -  with offenders being placed under various work release schemes.

 

     Last year, SCORE offered employment assistance to almost 3,000 offenders and ex-offenders.  To further enhance the assistance provided, SCORE launched an online drop portal in September last year.  Thus far, 443 employees have registered and 343 job vacancies have been posted online.  In total, 1,473 employers are registered with SCORE's job bank - up from 1,381 the year before.

     On our part, MHA, as a Ministry, has also been working on an e-portal to allow those who think they may benefit from the scheme to verify whether they have a criminal record that has been rendered as spent.  And this system will come into operation within the next one or two months.

 

     Sir, we all know that Government's efforts alone are not enough.  Employers, families and society at large must all play a part to change mindsets about ex-offenders.  For those determined to change for the better, we must extend helping hands, recognising it is the CARE network that launched the Yellow Ribbon project in the year 2004 - another ground-breaking initiative.  This project has grown from strength to strength.  For example, a Yellow Ribbon fare was held in the prison complex for the first time last year.  238 pre-release offenders took part in the job fare and 175 were offered jobs on the same day.  I am particularly pleased that the Yellow Ribbon project has galvanised community action.  I know of several groups, including employers and tertiary institution students, who have been inspired by the message behind the Yellow Ribbon to unlock the second prison, and they have come on board.  I think that is wonderful.  In particular, I want to thank the 125 new employers who offered jobs to ex-offenders last year.  Because I have said in Parliament before that getting new employers to come on board is one  key strategy that we must pursue more vigorously in the future.

 

     Mr Fong asked about the recidivism rate.  I am happy to share that all these efforts have resulted in lower recidivism rates which have declined steadily over the past few years.  In 1998, the recidivism rate peaked at 44.4%.  In other words, for every 100 released prisoners, about 50 returned to crime within two years.  But, today, the recidivism rate for the 2003 cohort - two-year span - has improved to 24.9%, the lowest rate thus far.

 

     Sir, in my remaining time, let me now deal with the other topics raised by Members.  First, Mr Fong talked about the question of emergency vehicles - how we can educate Singaporeans to give way to these vehicles.  I agree that public education is important, and we must get the maximum cooperation from our motoring public.  This is why the importance of doing so is covered in the basic theory of driving handbook, the advanced theory of driving handbook as well as the riding theory handbook.  As part of the training syllabus, the three driving schools, as well as private driving instructors, are also required to teach all learner drivers about the requirement to give way to an emergency vehicle.  In addition, questions regarding this rule are included in the driving and riding theory tests, which all motorists are required to pass before they are allowed to obtain the licence.

    

    Apart from educating learner drivers, Traffic Police also constantly reminds motorists of their obligation to give way to emergency vehicles through road safety talks, especially those targeted at private companies and Government agencies which own large fleets of vehicles, such as Chevron Texaco and SAF.  So it is a targeted approach.  68 such road safety talks were conducted in 2005, reaching to a total of about 10,000 drivers and riders.  I thank Mr Fong for highlighting this point.  This is one area that Singaporeans can do more about, and let us all continue to press home this message.

 

     Mr Ahmad Khalis would like to know whether the fire situation is improving and what more can be done through public education efforts.  Fire incidents have been declining over the past 10 years, from a high of over 6,700 fires in 1997 to 4,600 fires in 2003, down 30%.  In 2004, the number of fire incidents increased by 8% to some 4,916 fires; and last year, there was a marginal increase of 3% to 5,039 fires.  Last year, indeed, the marginal increase was attributed mainly to vegetation fires which, I am sure Mr Khalis remembers, besieged us for a while in the beginning part of the year.  But residential and non-residential related fires actually fell by 5% and 7% respectively last year, compared to the year before.

Here again, SCDF and CDEC members visited homes specifically to educate and to encourage them to desist from this act.

     Let me now answer Dr Maliki's two points.  He makes the first point about Subutex abuse and the second point about foreign spouses of Singaporeans who are here.  First, Subutex is, let me say, a prescription drug registered by the Health Sciences Authority for the treatment of opiate dependence.  It is regulated by the Ministry of Health under the Medicines Act and Poisons Act.  Since the abuse of Subutex first came to CNB's attention in late 2003, CNB has been working with MOH to explore possible measures to tackle the problem.  Last year, in November, MOH issued a set of clinical practice guidelines on the treatment of opiate dependence to doctors.  For example, doctors who wish to prescribe Subutex must undergo an 8-hour training course on opiate withdrawal and replacement therapy conducted by the Community Addictions Management Programme (CAMP) at the IMH.  At the same time, MOH has also set up a Central Addiction Registry for Drugs (CARDs), an online registry which allows the central monitoring

of all Subutex prescriptions to patients.  Doctors who prescribe Subutex are required to register their prescriptions in CARDS.  So in this way, doctors can monitor whether their patients are doctor-hopping. 

 

     Notwithstanding these control measures implemented by MOH, CNB is keeping a close watch on the situation.  The number of Subutex tablets seized monthly has increased from a high of more than 500 tablets in July last year to 180 tablets in December last year.  The number of public complaints and information received by CNB on Subutex abuse has also come down to 19 in December from a high of 31 in November last year.

 

     Dr Maliki has asked whether Subutex will be classified as a controlled drug under the MDA.  Given that MOH's control measures were implemented recently in November last year, I think we should allow some time for the measures to take effect and then we can assess.  But let me assure Dr Maliki that CNB remains vigilant and we will not hesitate to make Subutex a controlled drug, if the need arises. 

 

     Dr Maliki's second topic is on immigration and he has asked about the impact of our policies on immigration facilities for foreign spouses of Singapore and how we can better educate Singaporeans on the requirements.  First, let me assure Dr Maliki that our policies on long term immigration facilities take into account the preservation of family unity.  We are mindful of the need to manage this carefully, as the proportion of marriages involving a Singaporean and a foreign spouse has increased from about 21% in the year 2003 to almost 30% last year.

 

     But the Member well knows that marriage to a Singaporean does not automatically guarantee that the foreign spouse would be granted long-term immigration facilities.  However, even in cases where the foreign spouse is not eligible for Permanent Residence, we would still consider granting the foreign spouse a Long Term Social Visit Pass to enable him or her to remain in Singapore.

 

     So essentially, we need to ensure that foreigners given PR status do not become a burden to the State.  Basically, citizens and Permanent Residents sponsoring their foreign spouses or children of PR would need to show that they are able to support them financially.  Nevertheless, as I have said earlier, ICA adopts a sensitive and calibrated approach.  And based on ICA's records, the approval rates for PR and Long Term Social Visit Pass applications for foreign spouses have been relatively stable for the past three years, at 60% for PR cases and 85% for Long  Term Social Visit Pass cases.  So where appropriate, ICA now also has been providing applicants with the reasons for rejection, to help them understand what they can do to improve their eligibility when they re-apply.

 

      Sir, in short, ICA's guidelines governing the grant of long-term immigration facilities to foreign spouses are sufficiently compassionate to allow deserving spouses to stay in Singapore.  We will be keeping in mind the importance of sustaining their marriage and supporting family cohesion.

 

      Now, let me take Mr Loh Meng See's topic which is my last topic before my colleague, Mr Maidin, covers other aspects on the training and the professionalism of the Police Force.  Mr Loh Meng See's query is whether liquor licences are being issued too liberally, especially to provision shops and coffeeshops.  First, let me assure Mr Loh that Police takes a very careful approach in this because every application is assessed by Police.  So it is not a liberal approach.  Police takes into consideration factors, such as the location of the store and background of the applicant.  Since 1999, our figures showed only a very gradual increase of about 2.5% per year for all liquor licences.  So let me assure Mr Loh that there is no liberal policy when it comes to issuing liquor licences.

     Sir, this is an approach that we must continue to press on.  But I would encourage Mr Loh to continue to work with the Police and, indeed, let me know what other measures Police can take to help him manage this problem better.

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Home Affairs (Encik Mohamad Maidin B P M): Sir, I will now respond to some of the questions raised by Members concerning their Neighbourhood Police Centre (MPC) system, Home Team training and professionalism raised by Dr Maliki, Mr Ravindran and Mdm Ho Geok Choo yesterday.

 

     Firstly, Sir, Dr Maliki raised some questions about the NPC system and the level of Police presence on the ground.  Sir, the transition from the Neighbourhood Police Post (NPP) system to the NPC system started back in 1997 when the first NPC was established and was completed in 2001.  It was a strategic move by the Police to evolve and keep pace with the changes in the operating environment, and to improve the system of community policing.

 

     Currently, there is a nationwide network of about 32 NPCs supported by 65 Neighbourhood Police Posts (NPPs).  Under the NPC system, the NPPs still retain an operational role and have not been completely replaced. Overall, the number of service points has not changed significantly under the two systems.  There were 98 fixed service points under the previous system compared to 97 fixed service points today, comprising NPCs and NPPs.

 

     The operating hours of the existing NPPs have been shortened to allow for the redeployment of more officers for patrol duties during periods of lull activity at NPPs, in other words, more officers are being released to do patrol work.  This means their presence is more visible in the neighbourhood, rather than reduced. 

 

     Dr Maliki has also asked about the number of personnel assigned to police our housing estates under the NPP and NPC systems.  Sir, prior to the implementation of the NPC system, a total of 2,210 officers would patrol the total land area of Singapore.  Under the current system, this number increased to 2,761 officers, or an increase of more than 500 officers, or about 25%. This works out to a ratio of about one officer serving 1,580 residents as opposed to 1,700 in 1997.  This was achieved, although our population has increased from around $3.8 million to $4.35 million last year.  The increase in the number of officers is achieved through the optimisation of our police resources, including better utilisation of our full-time Police NSmen to complement the regulars in frontline duties.  The number of Police cars on patrol at any one time has more than doubled from 45 to 96, giving an average of three for each of the 32 NPCs.  Furthermore, in addition to the frontline NPC officers, we now also have strategic reserve forces from Special Operations Command and Key Installation Command, making regular patrols in designated areas to project greater Police visibility.

 

     Sir, it might however be recognised that effective policing is not determined solely by the number of police posts or police officers on the ground.  The public, as explained earlier, has a crucial role to play as well.  The cornerstone of our NPC system is the focus on developing community leadership and responsibility for the safety and security of the neighbourhoods.  In particular, the Community Safety and Security Programme (CSSP) and the Neighbourhood Watch Zones serve as useful platforms for the Home Team to connect with the grassroots leaders and residents to tackle local safety and security issues.

 

     Dr Maliki also asked about the key performance indicators (KPIs) of our NPCs.  Sir, the performance of the NPCs is measured under various KPIs, such as crime rates, response time and community engagement, which should reflect the corresponding emphasis on the NPC system.  We monitor these KPIs closely and there have been improvements in several areas.

      Members would like to note too that many of MFA's visiting delegations were also hosted to exhibitions, performances and exposed to our local culture.  During AMED last June, we took the opportunity to introduce our Middle East and other Asian guests to our prized local dishes like laksa, satay and chicken rice, and also embraced them in song and dance at the Malay Heritage Centre, complete with Yemeni-Arab music, which they greatly appreciated.  Recently, a Chinese delegation was hosted to the "Nutcracker" put up by the Singapore Dance Theatre at the Esplanade.  And during my visit to Indonesia last December, I was also able to establish links with South Sulawesi for cooperation between the Malay Heritage Centre and the Bugis connections in Makassar.  Where appropriate, we also showcase exhibitions by our local artists at our Singapore Art Museum, and/or the exhibitions at the Asian Civilisation Museum and our cultural heritage centres.  Active cultural diplomacy efforts by MFA are indeed on-going.

 

       According to MICA, which leads our international cultural cooperation efforts, seven G-G Cultural Agreements and six Agency-Agency Cultural Agreements have also been signed with countries such as China, India, South Korea, Jordan, Germany and Ireland over the past five years.  Our agencies, and through them our arts groups and companies, are encouraged to pursue whatever arrangement necessary to achieve our goals of internationalising our arts.  MFA will continue to assist our agencies in pursuing international cultural exchanges and in bringing Singapore culture to a wider international audience.

 

     In a wider context, I would also like to raise this question of inter-faith dialogue.  On the Prophet caricature issue, I think we all realise that religion plays an important part of living culture, so inter-faith dialogue is also important to our role.  The Prophet caricature issue has reminded us how sensitive religious divisions can be.  The Internet had quickly propagated what started as an issue in Europe to Southeast Asia as well.  Both President Yudhoyono and Prime Minister Badawi had to talk about it because their Muslim grounds had been aroused.  In ASEAN, we must not allow similar misunderstandings between Muslims and non-Muslims to surface, worse, to divide us.

 

      It is therefore in everyone's interest to have frequent, open and constructive dialogues involving key stakeholders, to address concerns and misperceptions.  This will help to defuse potential conflict amongst the different religions.  Singapore can play its part in promoting such inter-faith dialogue.  Earlier this year, the first Arab-Muslim Israeli Ambassador visited Singapore.  We would receive Cardinal Renato Raffaele Martino for the 25th Anniversary of Singapore-Holy See relations in June this year.  These are occasions where inter-faith dialogues could be organised.  It is educational for us, and we could benefit from the experience and wisdom of these personalities.  At the same time, we can contribute and share with them our own experiences.  These could be small but first steps towards eventually having a wider-based inter-faith dialogue forum in Singapore, a venue where different faiths could come together in open and constructive dialogue.

 

      I would also like to add that this concept of an inter-faith dialogue venue relates back to the fundamentals of Singapore's existence.  As a small country with no economic hinterland, our survival depends on us being able to remain relevant to the world.  Our foreign policy is designed to support this approach.  Singapore is now a key transport and logistics hub with efficient road networks, seaport and airport, as well as extensive air and sea links.  We are a political hub by virtue of being part of Southeast Asia that forms the core of key regional architectures

comprising APEC, ASEAN+3, ARF and EAS, and which is linked to other regions through ASEM, FEALAC and AMED.  You have earlier heard Minister George Yeo say that the region is at a political crossroads between two great civilisations, ie, China and India.  We are developing links with these countries because that is the way we want to encourage their presence in the region, just as with the US.  Economically, Singapore and the region are also actively developing ties with other countries and regions through FTAs and OSAs.  Singapore's role as a multi-dimensional global venue, or hub, will further contribute towards the region's engagement with major global players.
